title: 104_s1085
content:
The "Equal Opportunity Act of 1995" prohibits discrimination and preferential treatment. The "Equal Opportunity Act of 1995" prohibits intentional discrimination or preferential treatment based on race, color, national origin, or sex in federal contracts, employment, or programs. It also prohibits requiring or encouraging discrimination by federal contractors and subcontractors, as well as entering into consent decrees that allow such activities. The "Equal Opportunity Act of 1995" prohibits intentional discrimination or preferential treatment based on race, color, national origin, or sex in federal contracts, employment, or programs. It also prohibits authorizing any activity prohibited by paragraph (1) or (2). SEC. 3. RECRUITMENT AND ENCOURAGEMENT OF BIDS. The Act allows the Federal Government to recruit women and minorities for employment or encourage their businesses to bid for contracts without using preferences based on race or gender. It also permits the government to require contractors to do the same. The Act allows the Federal Government to include women and minorities in employment and contracting opportunities without using preferences based on race or gender. The Act allows for the inclusion of historically Black colleges and universities, Indian tribes, and considerations for sex as a bona fide occupational qualification. Classification for positions within the Federal Government or contractors/subcontractors may be necessary for normal operations, privacy protection, national security interests, or for members of the Armed Forces in combat operations. SEC. 5. COMPLIANCE REVIEW OF POLICIES AND REGULATIONS.

Within 1 year of this Act's enactment, each federal department or agency head, in consultation with the Attorney General, must review and modify existing policies and regulations to comply with this Act. They must report the results to the House and Senate Judiciary Committees.

SEC. 6. REMEDIES.

In any violation of this Act, a court can only award injunctive or equitable relief, attorney's fees, and costs. This does not affect remedies under other laws. SEC. 7. EFFECT ON PENDING MATTERS. This Act will not impact any cases, contracts, subcontracts, or consent decrees that are pending or in effect on the date of enactment. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. The term "Federal Government" refers to the executive and legislative branches of the United States. "Grant a preference" means giving preferential treatment, including quotas or numerical goals. A "historically Black college or university" is defined as a part B institution under the Higher Education Act of 1965.
